BulletinMeasurements.highlights: Road closures and the evacuation of especially endangered buildings are required.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs will become increasingly prone to triggering. As the snowfall becomes more intense numerous moist and wet avalanches are to be expected at any time, but they can be dangerously large.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2200 m. This applies especially until the early morning.
Avalanches can be released very easily and reach dangerously large size. Exposed buildings and exposed parts of transportation routes are endangered over a wide area in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers and can reach as far as low altitudes.
The conditions are treacherous for backcountry touring.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular in all altitude zones.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Over a wide area 70 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The peak danger point will be reached during the night.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: Road closures and the evacuation of especially endangered buildings are required.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs will become increasingly prone to triggering. As the snowfall becomes more intense numerous moist and wet avalanches are to be expected at any time, but they can be dangerously large.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2200 m. This applies especially until the early morning.
Avalanches can be released very easily and reach dangerously large size. Exposed buildings and exposed parts of transportation routes are endangered over a wide area in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers and can reach as far as low altitudes.
The conditions are treacherous for backcountry touring.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular in all altitude zones.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Over a wide area 70 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The peak danger point will be reached during the night.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual decrease in avalanche danger as the snowfall eases. Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and endanger exposed transportation routes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
From high-altitude starting zones in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanches can reach large size and in some places endanger transportation routes, including those situated at relatively low altitudes. This applies especially in the regions with a lot of snow.
Increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches until the temperature drops.
The conditions are very critical for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall over a wide area. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions. As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days.
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
Over a wide area 50 to 80 cm of snow will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual decrease in avalanche danger as the snowfall eases. Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and endanger exposed transportation routes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
From high-altitude starting zones in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanches can reach large size and in some places endanger transportation routes, including those situated at relatively low altitudes. This applies especially in the regions with a lot of snow.
Increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches until the temperature drops.
The conditions are very critical for ski touring, freeriding and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall over a wide area. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions. As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days.
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
Over a wide area 50 to 80 cm of snow will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs will become increasingly prone to triggering. Numerous dry and wet avalanches are to be expected at any time, but they can be dangerously large.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2200 m. This applies until the early morning.
Avalanches can be released very easily and reach dangerously large size. Exposed buildings and exposed parts of transportation routes are endangered in some cases in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
Below approximately 2200 m moist and wet avalanches are possible. In particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
The conditions are very dangerous for backcountry touring and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind, large wind slabs formed in particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain as well as at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Over a wide area 30 to 60 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The peak danger point will be reached by the early morning.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. As a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation there will be a gradual decrease in the danger of moist and wet avalanches as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last three days adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. As a consequence of wind from westerly directions, further wind slabs will form on Monday. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects.

During the day: Natural avalanches are further to be expected. The avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach large size in some cases. As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural activity of moist and wet avalanches will gradually decrease.
Avalanches can reach valley bottoms and in some places endanger exposed transportation routes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday above approximately 2000 m. Here rain fell up to 2000 m.
The southerly wind has transported the new snow significantly.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.

Sunday: Evening and night: Above approximately 2200 m 20 to 40 cm of snow will fall.
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Dry and moist avalanches are possible in some places.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: As a consequence of the heavy precipitation a large number of natural avalanches are to be expected, even large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A sometimes critical avalanche situation will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the large wind slabs that are being formed by the storm force to violent southerly wind can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. Large avalanches are to be expected. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. The peak of avalanche activity will be reached by the early morning probably. Evening: As the wind changes direction, the likelihood of natural dry avalanches being released will increase a little in particular at elevated altitudes.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized to large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are to be expected at any time, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on very steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. A lot of snow fell in the last few days over a wide area. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight decrease in danger of dry avalanches. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. Below approximately 2600 m: Wet and gliding snow require caution. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation a large number of wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even quite large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.highlights: As a consequence of the heavy precipitation a large number of natural avalanches are to be expected, even large ones.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A sometimes critical avalanche situation will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the large wind slabs that are being formed by the storm force to violent southerly wind can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. Large avalanches are to be expected. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. The peak of avalanche activity will be reached by the early morning probably. Evening: As the wind changes direction, the likelihood of natural dry avalanches being released will increase a little in particular at elevated altitudes.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized to large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are to be expected at any time, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on very steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. A lot of snow fell in the last few days over a wide area. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight decrease in danger of dry avalanches. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. Below approximately 2600 m: Wet and gliding snow require caution. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation a large number of wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even quite large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A critical avalanche situation will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from southerly directions, further wind slabs will form in the course of the day adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. As a consequence of the precipitation more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even large ones. On steep grassy slopes more medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 15 to 60 cm of snow will fall until Monday above approximately 2000 m. Until Monday the wind will be strong to storm force. In places that are protected from the wind wind slabs formed. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even quite large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual decrease in avalanche danger as a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the snowfall eases the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent by the early morning.
As the penetration by moisture increases more frequent wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses below approximately 2200 m.
The more recent wind slabs will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released easily and reach large size.
The current avalanche situation calls for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall over a wide area. The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual decrease in avalanche danger as a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As the snowfall eases the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent by the early morning.
As the penetration by moisture increases more frequent wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses below approximately 2200 m.
The more recent wind slabs will be covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise. New snow and wind slabs can in some places be released easily and reach large size.
The current avalanche situation calls for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to intermediate altitudes rain will fall over a wide area. The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last few days in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall until late morning above approximately 2300 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain easily released wind slabs will form. Skiers can release avalanches very easily, including large ones. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are probable.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall will give rise as the day progresses to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep slopes. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A precarious avalanche situation will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are being formed by the storm force to violent southerly wind can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. Occasionally large avalanches are possible. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. The peak of avalanche activity will be reached by the early morning probably. Evening: As the wind changes direction, the likelihood of natural dry avalanches being released will increase a little in particular at elevated altitudes.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on very steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight decrease in danger of dry avalanches. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Below approximately 2600 m: Wet and gliding snow require caution. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation a large number of wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution. As a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation there will be a gradual decrease in the danger of moist and wet avalanches as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of new snow and a sometimes strong wind from southerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs formed in the last three days adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas as well as above the tree line. As a consequence of wind from westerly directions, further wind slabs will form on Monday. They can be released easily or naturally in all aspects. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions these avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is greater.

During the day: Natural avalanches are further to be expected. The avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach medium size. As a consequence of falling temperatures, the natural activity of moist and wet avalanches will gradually decrease.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Saturday above approximately 2000 m. Here rain fell up to 2000 m.
The southerly wind has transported the new snow significantly.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.

Sunday: Evening and night: Above approximately 2200 m 15 to 30 cm of snow will fall.
The sleet will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Dry and moist avalanches are possible in some places.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day. In addition the wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the precipitation moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected, in particular medium-sized ones. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. On very steep grassy slopes more gliding avalanches are possible. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. On steep grassy slopes more medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 2 to 50 cm of snow will fall until Monday above approximately 1800 m. The rain will give rise as the day progresses to a loss of strength within the snowpack. The wind will be strong to storm force. In the vicinity of peaks wind slabs will form.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A precarious avalanche situation will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are being formed by the storm force to violent southerly wind can be released easily or naturally in all aspects above the tree line. Occasionally large avalanches are possible. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. The peak of avalanche activity will be reached by the early morning probably. Evening: As the wind changes direction, the likelihood of natural dry avalanches being released will increase a little in particular at elevated altitudes.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on very steep slopes in all aspects below the tree line.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall. This applies in particular above the tree line.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight decrease in danger of dry avalanches. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. Below approximately 2600 m: Wet and gliding snow require caution. As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation a large number of wet loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at intermediate and high altitudes. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
The rain will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects.
Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In the last few days wind slabs formed. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The weather conditions will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area light precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of the precipitation medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the rain small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. The rain will give rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: At low and intermediate altitudes a low danger of gliding avalanches and moist snow slides will be encountered in some localities.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 1700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally wet all the way through.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1900 m. In gullies and bowls a sometimes precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes. Some new snow above approximately 1900 m.
